ground_truth_answer: Japanese translation requires years of exposure to specific fields of interest and familiarity with time period-specific language variations, while understanding evidential expressions requires analysis of their semantic and logical properties. Translation demands practical experience with both modern and historical language usage, especially for older texts where kanji usage differs from modern standards. In contrast, evidential expressions require understanding their behavior in conditional contexts and their role in modal subordination. Both fields require specialized knowledge, but translation focuses on practical application and cultural-historical context, while evidential expression analysis centers on formal semantic properties and logical systems.
